First off I just want to say that I really like the concept of this game. The visuals are quite good, and the customize-able airship is fantastic! Very cool vibes overall too... flying between ruined skyscrapers and wind turbines and the like. It really is a nice setting for an atmospheric survival game (heh, see what I did there?)

That said, at the time of writing this review, this game is pretty devoid of content. After really sinking my teeth into it, there is sadly very little to do. The announcements say that Forever Skies is set to leave early access later THIS YEAR. I honestly don't see how that's possible unless there's a HUGE update in the works. In its current state, I was able to complete all the available content in this game in less than 1 in-game week. And that INCLUDES all the time I spent customizing my airship... There is very little diversity in the types of towers you can find, and the landscape is basically an endlessly procedurally generated assortment of mountains, ruined skyscrapers, and towers of various types. It's visually quite nice, but in terms of gameplay there just isn't enough to do on these towers to keep your attention for long. Normal towers come in 3 types, and each type has about 3-5 varieties that you can find. At one point you can enter a 4th type of tower that houses an elevator that goes below the "dust" layer that prevents your airship from descending too far. Unfortunately, every "underdust" environment is exactly identical to each other, meaning once you've seen one you've seen them all. Same is true for the other tower varieties. After only a dozen or so hours of playing I became quite familiar with everything that I could possibly encounter along my journey.

Story elements are also fairly minimal. There are some data pads to find along the way that help you understand a bit about the history of the environment you're exploring, but it's not very deep or surprising. Environmental catastrophe, nature reclaimed the planet, yadda yadda yadda. There are also some collectible objects and posters you can find randomly within the towers that you can then use to decorate your airship. After playing for a bit, I started to find a lot of duplicates of these objects, indicating that there isn't much variety to the cosmetic aspects of the game either.

At the end of the day, I still had some fun playing this game, and I understand it isn't yet finished... but it just feels unusually empty for a game that is supposedly close to a final release. I look forward to seeing whatever gets added next, but I don't have high hopes for this game feeling "finished" within the next year. Compared to many of the other survival/crafting games I've tried, this one needs a lot more content than it currently has if it's going to get a recommendation from me.

After watching the Starfield reveals, I developed a taste for games where I could not only fly but live on and customize my own ship. I wanted to be on something that would be my traveling home, my lifeline and my vehicle of exploration. Obviously I turned to Subnautica and Below Zero and as always they were excellent. I started searching for similar games which brought me to Forever Skies. This game is exactly what I was looking for and in many ways it captures that feeling better than Subnautica ever did. It all comes down to the sheer necessity of my mobile home. In Subnautica I can build a base and live there (which is great fun!) and never REALLY need my Cyclops submarine. A base and a seamoth will do just fine. But in Forever Skies, your airship is your life. You depend on it for everything. There you must cook, eat, drink, sleep, craft, store items, research and explore. You have to keep an eye on damage and fuel. You develop a daily routine. Get up, make water, make sure you have bait ready to go to "fish" for the big moths that fly around in the dangerous wastes below (I can't tell you how horrific it sounds to subsist on a diet of boiled moths!). The ship becomes your place in the world. It becomes the primary character in the game and you get to know every inch of it because you designed it from scratch.

The atmosphere in this game is amazing. You get up and walk outside onto the catwalk you've built and the wind sounds almost like a raging ocean. You go back inside and close the doors and the sound is muffled, serving as a psychological reprieve from the horrors outside. You suddenly feel safe in your flying fortress.

At first I had a very small airship and I was happy with it. It had everything I needed and I knew my way around perfectly. But the game pressures you to upgrade. You see your airship can only go so high (and so low), yet many of the platforms with life-saving materials and loot are too high for you to reach. So you have to upgrade your balloon which also allows you to build a bigger platform underneath. With the bigger platform comes more storage and amenities and room to breath. I've just finished upgrading my airship to what I'll call "phase two" and even though it's very simple and functional I'm proud of it. I visualized it and built it and it's my own. I don't want to turn this review into a comparison to  Subnautica because I love that game too, but let's face it, aside from some limited interior design and custom placement of storage lockers, etc., my Cyclops is exactly like your Cyclops and everyone else's who ever played that game. Not so with my Forever Skies airship.

I could go on and on about how much I love this game and the feeling it gives me when I play, but I don't really know where to begin or end. You get the picture.

Of course it is early access and there are some rough spots but none that have bothered me too much. I complained to the devs about the lack of rebinding options for the keyboard but that was fixed in the experimental branch. The game actually updated before I started writing this so maybe those changes have come to the main release itself. In truth, as the game stands now, it feels very polished, EA or no EA.

The immersion factor is superb and the ship is amazing. I've become addicted to this game world and I know as the development increases it will only get better. I'm sure many others have said this but I'll say it too: if you love Subnautica you'll love forever Skies.

I almost feel bad comparing it to Subnautica so much - the story is quite unique and surviving the harsh environments in the game is also quite different from Subnautica. But the inspiration is clear, and the mechanics are similar enough that one can't talk about this game for more than a minute without mentioning ... Subnautica.

First, a disclaimer: While I can't recommend the game in its current state, I'm hopeful that this will change sometime in the coming months. There's a solid skeleton here, but it needs a lot more meat on its bones before it gets a thumbs-up from me. 

Compared to other early access games, Forever Skies is very well polished. Even on launch day, I only noticed a handful of bugs in my 6 hours of playtime, all minor interface issues that were easily remedied. The game looks good, the airship design mechanics work well, and exploring the world feels natural. I caught a couple of tools that seemed to be missing their sound effects, and spotted at least one spelling mistake in the interface, but that still puts it in the "exceeds expectations" category for me.  

While the content is polished, though, there just isn't a lot of it. Six hours was enough for me to reach the end of the story, and that was at a rather leisurely pace. About a third of that consisted of puttering about over a ruined city, landing atop various towers, looting them for resources, and generally having a blast. Another third was dedicated to inventory management, shooting mining lasers at alien tumbleweeds, and using the resources thus gained to craft more small boxes to help manage my inventory. 

The last third of the game involved docking my ship at a big tower and exploring a cramped and confusing dungeon area. At this point, the free-roaming gameplay I'd been enjoying was replaced with a simple, tedious loop: 
1. Go down the elevator.
2. Run around until I hit a barrier.
3. Grab or scan something nearby. 
4. Go up the elevator to research the thing.
5. Repeat. 

Parts of it were visually stunning, but being on a 100-second oxygen timer meant I was scrambling to and fro too fast to really appreciate it. After a few cycles of this, the end arrived without much fanfare. I could return to the clouds and set sail again in search of new furniture or compartments, but I'd run out of truly novel content. Compared to other games in the genre, it felt like I ran out of road right when it should be starting to get good. 

Right now, Forever Skies feels like a pitch for the game the developers want to make. There are lots of hooks that aren't really expanded on, indications of what content might arrive in the future, but what's there now is just enough to whet the appetite. I very much like the look of that future game, and hope to see it come to fruition. 

If you just can't wait to sink your teeth into a surprisingly robust demo, and you don't mind gambling a decent chunk of your money to do so, you might consider picking up Forever Skies now. If not, I still suggest keeping this game on your wishlist and following its future development. If the devs can stay on track with their planned updates, this could become one of my favorites games in the genre..

There are bases and outposts that litter the sky atop wind farms, comm towers, and skyscrapers where people tried to survive. In these location you can find needed items, tools, blueprints, and items to scan so you can learn about them or fabricate them for use.

There are several stations that do various jobs that you can place on your airship. There are currently several styles of furniture you can discover the blueprints for by going to all the locations. All can be solved by carefully searching the areas, reading messages laying around or crafting items. 

You will acquire a scanner tool. Use this on anything you can. It will give you blueprints, lore, important info, and required knowledge and the ability to craft items. Try to explore ever square foot of a location for supplies, relics, and other useful things. Create crates to store the most valuable ones in.

BUILDING THE AIRSHIP: You start out with a small humble airship to travel to other locations but as you do you pick up necessary materials and blueprints to expand the airship.
